https://github.com/react-native-community/lottie-react-native

Used by 62k repos and about 12k stars. 

> Lottie component for React Native (iOS and Android)
>

title: [Onboarding] Create template for 'react-native init'

labels.name: Deliverable
labels.description: Major item tracked for top-level planning in ADO

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
The `react-native init` tool allows a user to specify a template that swaps out the typical Hello World app that the CLI tool produces with some custom template. A nice example of this is the Typescript starter template, which you would use by running:
```
react-native init MyApp --template typescript
```

We should smooth out the onboarding experience for `react-native-windows` by creating a template, so you would only need to run:
```
react-native init MyApp --template windows
```
Rather than:
```
react-native init MyApp
yarn add rnpm-plugin-windows
react-native windows
```

title: Provide a hook for registering global keyboard shortcuts

labels.name: Deliverable
labels.description: Major item tracked for top-level planning in ADO

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
Copied from Andrew's suggestion below:

Basic design should be something like:
https://johannesklauss.github.io/react-hotkeys-hook/docs-use-hotkeys

We could have the key should be specified as a single string, as in the above package, but I think it probably makes more sense to stick with the interface we have on our keyboarding events, which would take an object:
```
  useHotkeys({key: 'N', ctrlKey: true}, () => setAmount(prevAmount => prevAmount + 100));
```
An array should probably also be an option (in the above library a , deliminated string is valid:
```
  useHotkeys([ {key: 'N', ctrlKey: true}, {key: 'A'} ], () => setAmount(prevAmount => prevAmount + 100));
```
Some thought should be done on if we need to have some way of specifying if it should mark the accelerator as handled.

body:
Some components don't have appropriate focus visuals when they receive keyboard focus.

- [ ] FlatList - Focus rect is drawn around the entire component
- [ ] FlatList - User can't move focus to a specific item using arrow keys
- [ ] SectionList - focus rect
- [ ] SectionList - arrow keys

May be related to #3006
- [ ] Popup (non light-dismiss) - should not trap focus (currently, always traps focus, which is correct for light-dismiss case)

title: Need APIs for custom tab navigation

labels.name: Deliverable
labels.description: Major item tracked for top-level planning in ADO

labels.name: must-have
labels.description: p1

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:

- Turbo Module support

body:
<!-- This is a template for new feature or API proposals for React Native Windows. Use this to submit new API/component requests or behavior updates that are specific to Windows-only. For feature requests to React Native, go [here](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals) instead. 

It's fine if you don't have all the details for the template below: you can start with the Summary and Rationale. Read more about React Native for Windows proposal process [here](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/tree/master/vnext/proposals)
-->

# Proposal: Need APIs for custom tab navigation
<!-- Add a title for your feature or API proposal. Please be short and descriptive -->

## Summary
This proposal tracks the need to expose new APIs for apps to customize tab navigation and focus management when the default behaviors are not sufficient for their scenarios.

## Motivation

<!-- Why are we doing this? What use cases does it support? What is the expected outcome? Why should this be done for Windows-only?

Please focus on explaining the motivation so that if this proposal is not accepted, the motivation could be used to develop alternative solutions. In other words, enumerate the constraints you are trying to solve without coupling them too closely to the solution you have in mind. -->

Native controls support default tab navigation and focus visuals. We also just introduced Keyboard events and some default key stroke behaviors in Milestone 2. The next scenarios that need to be enabled to complete this story are around customizing tab navigation when the default behaviors are not sufficient.  

## Proposed solution(s)
Introduce the following APIs:
1.  `tabIndex` : specifies the tab order of the element in integer values. 
   - If this value is 0, the default tab order will be followed.
   - If this is set to <0, that element will be ignored in tab-order. 
See [HTML-tabIndex](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/att_tabindex.asp) and [XAML-TabIndex](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.ui.xaml.controls.control.tabindex) for reference. We should deprecate the Windows-only API `acceptsKeyboardFocus` once this prop is added since negative values for tabIndex serve all the scenarios that this separate property used to.

~~Alternate option: We can introduce tabIndex without the "-1" behavior and retain `acceptsKeyboardFocus` as a separate property. This matches more closely with Windows behavior. It also supports scenarios where dynamically enabling tabbing on a View can be done independent of the tab order of that View.~~

2. `focusZone` and `focusTrapZone` components will be created in a separate package. These will follow the pattern of fabric React [focusTrapZone](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/#/controls/web/focustrapzone) and [focusZone](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/#/controls/web/focuszone) APIs and will be implemented using the native [XAML Control.TabNavigation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.ui.xaml.controls.control.tabnavigation) APIs.

~~Alternate option: Add tabNavigation prop similar to the XAML approach.~~

### Not in scope:

-  `nextFocusForward` : specifies the next element in the tab order. This is a currently supported API in RN only for [Android](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/View.html#attr_android:nextFocusForward) and helps with the scenario where default tabbing mostly works and apps need one or two places where they want to customize the next element in the tab order.

We are not adding this property since there is a lot of collision behaviors with tabIndex and tabIndex seems to be more useful and solves all the scenarios that nextFocusForward supports.

title: Add autoFocus property to View

Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

- Turbo Module support

body:
<!-- This is a template for new feature or API proposals for React Native Windows. Use this to submit new API/component requests or behavior updates that are specific to Windows-only. For feature requests to React Native, go [here](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals) instead. 

It's fine if you don't have all the details for the template below: you can start with the Summary and Rationale. Read more about React Native for Windows proposal process [here](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/tree/master/vnext/proposals)
-->

# Proposal: Need ability to set initial focus on any UI component
<!-- Add a title for your feature or API proposal. Please be short and descriptive -->

## Summary
<!-- Brief explanation of the new API or change. -->
React Native has an `autoFocus` property on `TextInput` element today which allows developers to set initial focus to a TextInput component. We should move/add this property to `View` instead to support keyboard focus. 

## Motivation

<!-- Why are we doing this? What use cases does it support? What is the expected outcome? Why should this be done for Windows-only?

Please focus on explaining the motivation so that if this proposal is not accepted, the motivation could be used to develop alternative solutions. In other words, enumerate the constraints you are trying to solve without coupling them too closely to the solution you have in mind. -->
With React Native, the mobile-centric usecases are mostly served by having focus concepts only on `TextInput`. This is no longer true in Windows as we have added all focus concepts to View since keyboard focus can be placed on any UI component and react-native-windows apps should be navigable through Keyboard. 

Adding `autoFocus` to `View` completes this story. This was requested by Xbox team. 

## Basic example

<!-- [Optional] If the proposal involves a new or changed API, include a basic code example. Omit this section if it's not applicable. -->
With the below code, the initial focus should be on the Button. 

```xml
<View>
   <Button title="Click to read privacy policy"
      autoFocus="true"
      onPress={() => Alert.alert('Privacy policy blah blah text')}
        />
   <Text>Enter your name:</Text>
   <TextInput />
</View>
```
## Open Questions

<!-- Please list any open issues that you think still need to be addressed.
These could include areas you think would benefit from community or the react-native-windows team input -->
1. Should this be proposed back to React Native and not necessarily remain in react-native-windows?

labels.description: Major item tracked for top-level planning in ADO

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). body: [AppState](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/appstate) is the API in ReactNative that detects whether or not the app has focus (is in Foreground vs Background). ## Today's Behavior on Desktop: - ```active``` App is running and has focus App is running and does not have focus - ```background``` App is running and minimized - ```inactive``` Does not occur. Default scenarios where this would get triggered are Mobile-specific ## Proposed Changes to Behavior on Desktop - ```active``` App is running and has focus - ```background``` App is running and minimized App is running and does not have focus App is running but alt-tab is being preformed - ```inactive``` **Occurs when Task View is opened* **Start menu is opened in Tablet mode* > *Need to review ones with respective team and key scenario owners. ## Reasoning There are essentially **6** different states that an app can be when on desktop as opposed to mobile's **4**: *(RBG is the app who's AppState we are concerned about in these examples)* - Active ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964369/54299526-4e167f00-4578-11e9-9e49-6d3383c35aae.png) - Not minimized, but does not have focus (another window does) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964369/54299619-8453fe80-4578-11e9-919b-a8afc9001fd5.png) - Not minimized, but does not have focus (alt-tab menu does) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964369/54299681-a3529080-4578-11e9-9e9b-48332948709c.png) - Minimized ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964369/54299742-bcf3d800-4578-11e9-940c-6a2f801acea0.png) - Inactive because Task View is open ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964369/54299773-cc732100-4578-11e9-85aa-f9d5d5db96fd.png) - Inactive in Tablet mode when Start Menu is open *(image coming)*

For feature requests to React Native, go [here](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals) instead. 

It's fine if you don't have all the details for the template below: you can start with the Summary and Rationale. Read more about React Native for Windows proposal process [here](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/tree/master/vnext/proposals)
-->

# Proposal: Add support for Direct Debugging
<!-- Add a title for your feature or API proposal. Please be short and descriptive -->

## Summary
React-native has direct debugging on other platforms.  My understanding is this allows you to debug the javascript running directly in-proc rather than out-of-proc over a websocket connection.  We don't support this yet in vnext.  This issue is tracking adding support.

## Motivation

<!-- Why are we doing this? What use cases does it support? What is the expected outcome? Why should this be done for Windows-only?

Please focus on explaining the motivation so that if this proposal is not accepted, the motivation could be used to develop alternative solutions. In other words, enumerate the constraints you are trying to solve without coupling them too closely to the solution you have in mind. -->

## Basic example

<!-- [Optional] If the proposal involves a new or changed API, include a basic code example. Omit this section if it's not applicable. -->

## Open Questions

<!-- Please list any open issues that you think still need to be addressed.
These could include areas you think would benefit from community or the react-native-windows team input -->

But this throws a bunch of weird errors. I was able to get it to work when switching to using

Any chance it can be properly piped through react-native?

using versions
"react-native": "0.59.0-microsoft.68"
"react-native-windows": "^0.59.0-vnext.157",

Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:

- Turbo Module support

body:
WebView used to come from react-native.
`import { WebView } from 'react-native';`
but it's been moved to 
`import { WebView } from 'react-native-webview';`
https://github.com/react-native-community/react-native-webview

When using webview from this, it has only ios and android implementation. And thus falls back on default web version for windows. Which then throws an exception because its fully deprecated in RN60.

# Proposal: Add support for auto-linking native modules.  Also consider implementing react-native link (lower priority)
<!-- Add a title for your feature or API proposal. Please be short and descriptive -->

## Summary
With version 60, react-native now supports auto-linking.  This item is tracking making sure RNW supports it as well.  See https://facebook.github.io/react-native/blog/2019/07/03/version-60

In addition we can consider implementing the Linking native module.  See:  https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/linking
We'll use this issue to decide whether or not we actually do this work as it might be unnecessary.

## Motivation

<!-- Why are we doing this? What use cases does it support? What is the expected outcome? Why should this be done for Windows-only?

Please focus on explaining the motivation so that if this proposal is not accepted, the motivation could be used to develop alternative solutions. In other words, enumerate the constraints you are trying to solve without coupling them too closely to the solution you have in mind. -->

title: Measure and document core feature parity

labels.name: Deliverable
labels.description: Major item tracked for top-level planning in ADO

labels.name: must-have
labels.description: p1

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
# Proposal: Document which React Native APIs are and are not supported by React Native for Windows

## Details

We've previously tracking core parity with various one-off issues.
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/2136
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/2113
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/2111
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/2796
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/3016
These were built from canvasing partners and getting a rough breakdown of priority based on immediate need.

As tracking the long list of issues with sub-issue checkboxes became unwieldy I split those out into issues and created project boards to track overall progress and ordering:
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/projects/17
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/projects/18
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/projects/19
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/projects/20
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/projects/21
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/projects/22

There's a couple parts here:
1. Make sure we don't miss any APIs
2. Document our implemented/not-implemented state on all APIs

We want an easy to consult source of truth on #2 that has a reasonable plan for how to keep up to date (at least until we have a plan to integrate that status directly into the official RN docs). What form it takes is less important. It could be a spreadsheet, a doc on the wiki, a file checked into the repo. Savoy created a detailed approach for Accessibility here which is a good reference: #3016 

Simplifying that to remove tracking of iOS/Android, Current vs. vNext, RN59 vs. RN90... we could be fine with just this:

| API | Status |
| :--- |  :----: |
| **Text Props** |  |
| accessible | Yes |
| accessibilityHint  | Yes |
| accessibilityLabel | Yes |
| accessibilityRole | #3111 |
| accessibilityState | #3111 |

Where each API has these possible states:
- Implemented
- Not implemented, with link to issue tracking future implementation
- Never will be implemented, with link to discussion (or that information is provided inline)

FYI, many (but not all) of the issues are being tracked with this label: https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/labels/API%20Completion
That may help seed, but we really need a fresh diff from the official RN docs as of RN60

Note that we want fine-grained detail here, but whatever solution we land here should also roll up into this: https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/master/vnext/docs/ParityStatus.md

title: <Image> component should support static svg files

labels.name: Deliverable
labels.description: Major item tracked for top-level planning in ADO

labels.name: must-have
labels.description: p1

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
In RN4W, the react-native Image component currently only supports anything that a LoadedImageSurface can load.  This is limited to image file formats (eg JPG, PNG, etc), and not svg.

This issue is tracking allowing the Image react-native component to support .svg files.  Internally XAML does support svg, through both Image and SvgImageSource.  XAML's imaging code needs to know ahead of time if the file is an svg before decoding.  Image.Source has some logic to auto-detect .svg/.svgz file extensions.  At the lower level we have SvgImageSource that's used explicitly for svg files.

What I think the above means for our code is that we should probably do a file extension check and if it is .svg/.svgz, create an SvgImageSource. 

In addition, we'll need a new code path that uses an ImageBrush + SvgImageSource instead of LoadedImageSurface + XCBB.

body: Native Module developers should be able to define custom structs with primitive fields, and use them as event args, similar to #3217.

body:
Right now we do the work under the covers to convert RN color values for properties into Brushes.

We should instead:

1. Expose those APIs as utility functions
2. Pass the raw property values up to external view managers (with the reader/writers/jsvalues)
3. Let the external view manager do the conversion when necessary by calling the API

title: Ensure properties and colors set through React Native styling map to native controls reasonably

labels.name: needs PM design
labels.description: New feature or request

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
This issue covers the work we'll need to do to ensure that the styling set on components at the Javascript React Native level translate as nicely as possible to the native controls. # Theming in React Native for windows There are many easy ways to color and theme JavaScript components in RN through CSS, but the reverse (targeting brushes or colors of native controls) is a bit trickier. ## Levels of styling to be exposed We will be introducing two different levels of styling, one being what we'll be pushing into lean core React Native, and only we will be implementing for the Windows module only (Windows "extended" if you will). ### [P0] Styling native lean core components in React Native In this case, the table defined above is the extent of the customization capabilities available to the RN app-developer at the JS layer. They will have to live with the native's choice for hover and other state colors/styles unless they choose to consume the Windows extended module (defined in next section). > **Open Issue:** Currently looking for feedback from community around introducing a "pressedColor". This property would be mapped to the native control's corresponding "main" color, and in the XAML-case would override the VSM property for that color on the pressed state. #### If pressed events were added to lean core If the above open issue were to be closed, proposed, and implemented into vanilla React Native, we could expect one extra layer of component state customization, that could look something like this: ``` JavaScript const styles = StyleSheet.create({ myPickerStyle: { width: 200, height: 45, backgroundColor: 'red', pressedColor: 'dark gray', pressedBackgroundColor: 'white', }, }); ``` ### [P1] Styling native lean core components in RN Windows extended In this case we will be exposing all of the properties, in every state, that exist on each lean core component. For example, we would have enough properties exposed on our lean core components in Windows extended to enable scenarios such as this: ``` JavaScript const styles = StyleSheet.create({ myPickerStyle: { width: 200, height: 45, backgroundColor: 'red', Platform.select({ windows: { backgroundColorHover: 'dark red', borderColorHover: 'grey', }, }), }, }); ``` Where the `backgroundColorHover` and `borderColorHover` in the `Picker` control case would map to the XAML lightweight styling resources `ComboBoxBackgroundPointerOver` and `ComboBoxBorderBrushPointerOver`, respectively. ## [P2] Expand the windowsBrush capabilities Currently, the ``windowsBrush`` API in the React Native Windows implementation handles system colors only. This proposal asks to expand that API's capabilities to handle: ``` const styles = StyleSheet.create({ someViewStyle: { width: 200, height: 45, backgroundColor: {windowsBrush: 'ButtonBackground'}, }, someOtherViewStyle: { alignItems: center; backgroundColor: {windowsBrush: 'SystemControlBackgroundBaseMediumBrush'}, } }); ``` ## [P0] Stylesheet properties align with XAML native properties The general approach to control customization in React Native is to build your own control from primitives, and therefore be able to easily access any and all parts to color them accordingly. However, in the case where you want to color or theme a native control - i.e. want to access it's native properties to set the colors yourself without building it out of primitives - we should look at how we can do this by mapping the css-like properties specified in the JS stylesheets to the native control properties, should they exists. >The following are modified tables from [this open source readme](https://github.com/vhpoet/react-native-styling-cheat-sheet/blob/master/README.md). This list looks at what React Native properties exist in the stylesheets that could be mapped to the **lean core** controls on the XAML side. >This will not take into account how these set of properties could/do apply to container controls in XAML, like View -> Canvas/Grid etc. This is **not** looking at XAML primitives, only UIElements in general. | RN CSS Property | RN Default | XAML Control Property Equivalent | |------|---------|-------------| | alignContent | | `HorizontalAlignment`
`VertcialAlignment` | | aspectRatio | [number](#number) | `MinHeight`?
`MinWidth` ? | | borderBottomWidth | [number](#number) |`BorderThickness(0, 0, 0, value)` | | borderLeftWidth | [number](#number) | `BorderThickness(value, 0, 0, 0)`| | borderRightWidth | [number](#number) | `BorderThickness()
0, 0, value, 0)`| | borderTopWidth | [number](#number) | `BorderThickness(0, value, 0, 0)`| | borderEndWidth | [number](#number)
*When direction is ltr, `borderEndWidth` is equivalent to `borderRightWidth`.
When direction is rtl, `borderEndWidth` is equivalent to `borderLeftWidth`.* | `BorderThickness(0, 0, value, 0)`
OR
`BorderThickness(value, 0, 0, 0)`
Depending | | borderStartWidth | [number](#number)
*When direction is ltr, ``borderStartWidth`` is equivalent to ``borderLeftWidth``.
When direction is rtl, ``borderStartWidth`` is equivalent to ``borderRightWidth``.* | `BorderThickness(value, 0, 0, 0)`
OR
`BorderThickness(0, 0, value, 0)`
Depending | | borderWidth | [number](#number) | `BorderThickness(value, value, value, value)`
If set to **thin**:
`BorderThickness(1, 1, 1, 1)`
If set to **medium**:
`BorderThickness(3, 3, 3, 3)`
If set to **thick**:
`BorderThickness(5, 5, 5, 5)` | | direction | [oneOf](#oneof) `inherit`, `ltr`, `rtl` | `FlowDirection`| | height | [number](#number) |`Height`| | margin | [number](#number) | `Margin(value, value, value, value)` | | marginBottom | [number](#number) | `Margin(0, 0, 0, value)` | | marginHorizontal | [number](#number) | `Margin(value, 0, value, 0)` | | marginLeft | [number](#number) | `Margin(value, 0, 0, 0)` | | marginRight | [number](#number) | `Margin(0, 0, value, 0)` | | marginTop | [number](#number) | `Margin(0, value, 0, 0)` | | marginVertical | [number](#number) | `Margin(0, value, 0, value)` | | marginEnd | [number](#number)
*When direction is `ltr`, `marginEnd` is equivalent to `marginRight`.
When direction is `rtl`, `marginEnd` is equivalent to `marginLeft`.* | `Margin(0, 0, value, 0)`
OR
`Margin(value, 0, 0, 0)`| | marginStart | [number](#number)
*When direction is `ltr`, `marginStart` is equivalent to `marginLeft`.
When direction is `rtl`, `marginStart` is equivalent to `marginRight`.* | `Margin(value, 0, 0, 0)`
OR
`Margin(0, 0, value, 0)` | | maxHeight | [number](#number) | `MaxHeight` | | maxWidth | [number](#number) | `MaxWidth` | | minHeight | [number](#number) | `MinHeight` | | minWidth | [number](#number) | `MinWidth` | | padding | [number](#number), [string](#string) | `Padding(value, value, value, value)`| | paddingBottom | [number](#number), [string](#string) | `Padding(0, 0, 0, value)` | | paddingHorizontal | [number](#number), [string](#string) | `Padding(value, 0, value, 0)`| | paddingLeft | [number](#number), [string](#string) |`Padding(value, 0, 0, 0)` | | paddingRight | [number](#number), [string](#string) | `Padding(0, 0, value, 0)`| | paddingTop | [number](#number), [string](#string) | `Padding(0, value, 0, 0)`| | paddingVertical | [number](#number), [string](#string) | `Padding(0, value, 0, value)` | | paddingEnd | [number](#number), [string](#string)
*When direction is `ltr`, `paddingEnd` is equivalent to `paddingRight`.
When direction is `rtl`, `paddingEnd` is equivalent to `paddingLeft`.* | `Padding(0, 0, value, 0)`
OR
`Padding(value, 0, 0, 0)` | | paddingStart | [number](#number), [string](#string)
*When direction is `ltr`, `paddingStart` is equivalent to `paddingLeft`.
When direction is `rtl`, `paddingStart` is equivalent to `paddingRight`.* | `Padding(value, 0, 0, 0)`
OR
`Padding(0, 0, value, 0)` | | width | [number](#number) | `Width` | | color| `ColorPropType` | `Foreground` *(If natively text, else do nothing)* | | fontFamily | [string](#string) | `FontFamily` *(where applicable, else do nothing)* | | fontSize | [number](#number) | `FontSize` *(where applicable, else do nothing)* | | fontStyle | [oneOf](#oneof) `normal`, `italic`
**TO BE ADDED** Windows only: `oblique` | `FontStyle` | | fontVariant | [arrayOf](#arrayof)([oneOf](#oneof)`small-caps`, `oldstyle-nums`, `lining-nums`, `tabular-nums`, `proportional-nums`) | No equivalent | | textTransform | [oneOf](#oneof) `none`, `uppercase`, `lowercase`, `capitalize` | No equivalent | | fontWeight | [oneOf](#oneof) `normal`, `bold`, `100`, `200`, `300`, `400`, `500`, `600`, `700`, `800`, `900` | `FontWeight` *(where applicable, else do nothing)* | | includeFontPadding | [bool](#bool) | No equivalent | | lineHeight | [number](#number) | `LineHeight` *(where applicable, else do nothing)* | | textAlign | [oneOf](#oneof) `auto`, `left`, `right`, `center`, `justify`
**TO BE ADDED** Windows only: `DetectFromCenter`, `Start`, `End` | `TextAlignment` *(where applicable, else do nothing)*| | textDecorationLine | [oneOf](#oneof) `none`, `underline`, `line-through` | `TextDecoration` *(where applicable, else do nothing)* | | backfaceVisibility | [oneOf](#oneof) `visible`, `hidden` | `Visibility="Collapsed/Visible"` | | backgroundColor | `ColorPropType` | `Background` | | borderBottomEndRadius | [number](#number) | ? | | borderBottomStartRadius | [number](#number) | ? | | borderBottomLeftRadius | [number](#number) | 'CornerRadius(0, 0, 0, value)' | | borderBottomRightRadius | [number](#number) | 'CornerRadius(0, 0, value, 0)' | | borderColor | `ColorPropType` | `BorderBrush` | | borderRadius | [number](#number) | `CornerRadius(value, value, value, value)` | | borderStyle | [oneOf](#oneof) `solid`, `dotted`, `dashed` | No equivalent | | borderTopEndRadius | [number](#number) | ? | | borderTopStartRadius | [number](#number) | ? | | borderTopLeftRadius | [number](#number) | `CornerRadius(value, 0, 0, 0)` | | borderTopRightRadius | [number](#number) | `CornerRadius(0, value, 0, 0)` | | opacity | [number](#number) | `Opacity` | **To be added** | RN CSS Property | RN Default | XAML Control Property Equivalent | |------|---------|-------------| | pressedColor | `ColorPropType` | XAML control lightweight styling *foreground* color equivalent | | pressedBackgroundColor | `ColorPropType` | XAML control lightweight styling *background/"main"* color equivalent | * properties with default value `auto` marked with asterisk are do not actually have `auto` as their default value, they just behave like if they would in *css* if they had `auto` as their value. `auto` is not valid value for those properties in react-native

body:
We don't need or want both, and it's confusing.

Also need to move to cppwinrt from WRL implementation

Also need to remove module.g.cpp. Currently we need to maintain it [manually](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3622/commits/bea64a8094813f5055b57ac19b203e91742af152). So we should use the one in `Generated Files` folder.

title: Refactor Chakra and ChakraCore jsi::Runtime implementations into a class hierarchy.
body:
Since Chakra and ChakraCore has similar but slightly differnt APIs, we've relying heavily on conditional compilation: We use the macro USE_JSRT_EDGEMODE to check whether we are linking with Chakra.dll or ChakraCore.dll, causing code to be very difficult to navigate at times. Using USE_JSRT_EDGEMODE to perform this check is also fundamentally wrong, since it is the macro that toggles whether chakrart.h (header for chakra.dll) or jsrt9.h (header for legacy IE engine) in #included when one #include jsrt.h.

This PR:
- Removes checks for USE_JSRT_EDGEMODE within JSI code. We now use the (existing) CHAKRACORE macro for checking whether we are linking against Chakra or ChakraCore.
- Refactors the current Chakra and ChakraCore jsi::Runtime implementations into a class hierarchy. The base class ChakraRuntime contains the functionalities of jsi::Runtime that can be implemented by APIs available to both Chakra and ChakraCore. Functionalities that need to or should be implemented using Chakra or ChakraCore specific APIs are implemented by the derived classes ChakraRtRuntime and ChakraCoreRuntime, respectively. The name "ChakraRtRuntime" comes from the header that gets #included by jsrt.h when USE_EDGEMODE_JSRT is #defined.

Note that there are still some conditional compilation based on the CHAKRACORE macro. Most of them are in ChakraObjectRef.h/cpp and all have comments explaining why they are there. The rest are used to make sure that, when a specific engine is used, only the corresponding jsi::Runtime is compiled.

Summary of each iteration:
1. Rename ChakraRunitme_edge.cpp into ChakraRtRuntime.cpp. Rename ChakraRuntime_core.cpp to ChakraCoreRuntime.cpp
2. Move ChakraRuntimeHolder.cpp to Shared.
3. Refactor ChakraRuntime into a class hierarchy. This makes up the majority of this PR.
4. Reimplement ChakraRuntimeHolder based on the refactored architecture.
5. Clean up JSI.Desktop.UnitTests, since with the new architecture, it no longer need to depend on ReactWindowsCore.
6. Remove the extra copy of ChakraRuntimeHolder in Desktop.IntegrationTests.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3677)

title: Live-reload fails after a bit

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)

Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

body:
### Environment

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->

1. `react-native -v`: 
```
react-native-cli: 2.0.1
react-native: 0.60.6
```
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`:
```
blankproject@0.0.1 C:\Users\kisai\Documents\RN4W\IgniteDemos\demoproject
`-- rnpm-plugin-windows@0.2.13
```
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`:
```
blankproject@0.0.1 C:\Users\kisai\Documents\RN4W\IgniteDemos\demoproject
`-- react-native-windows@0.60.0-vnext.4
```
4. `node -v`:
```
v10.15.1
```
5. `npm -v`:
```
6.4.1
```

Then, specify:
- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.18865
- Target Device(s): Desktop/UWP
- Visual Studio Version: 2017
- Build Configuration: Debug

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesnt know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->

1. Create an app
2. Launch server
3. Build and deploy app
4. Make some changes and save
5. Watch live-reload update
6. Repet 4-5 until live-reload stops updating

### Expected Behavior

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  Its fine if youre not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->

I would expect it to continue to live-reload, not stop after a certain period of time.

### Actual Behavior

<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
  Describe this section in detail, and attach screenshots if possible.
  Don't just say "it doesn't work"!
-->

After a while it just shows a blank white app and doesn't reload anything.

title: Consistent naming convention throughout the repo.
body: Currently the repo used a weird mix of Microsoft's and Facebook's naming conventions. For example, some functions are camelCase (Facebook's convention), while some are PascalCase (Microsoft's convention). We need a somewhat consistent naming convention through out the whole repo. Everything under the Microsoft namespace should follow Microsoft's conventions, and everything under the facebook namespace should follow facebook's conventions.

title: Fix Driver letter casing problem on metro/node_haste

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
Driver-letter casing contributed to the ```error Unable to resolve module `warnOnce` ```, and it's hard to debug. 
This problem is found when I made `react-native bundle` in msbuild, and it always failed in the VS IDE and VS code IDE, but passed in cmd.exe. Finally I figured out the problem is related to the driver letter casing.

I didn't narrow down the problem to which line of code yet. From high level and logs, I found the we may run into `warOnce` error based on your windows and your environment 

I don't think it has impact on Linux and Mac, so Windows is the only victim. and it's high possibility that RNW customer hits this too. we need to resolve it and contribute it back to metro/node_haste.

Its very easy to reproduce it by steps like below. At the beginning, it's `c:\\`, run the bundle command, then switch it to `C:\\` and run the bundle again. one of the bundle command may fail. 

c:\repo\react-native-windows\packages\E2ETest>yarn run bundle
c:\repo\react-native-windows\packages\E2ETest>cd ..\..

c:\repo\react-native-windows>cmd /K cd /d "C:\repo\react-native-windows\packages\E2ETest"
**C**:\repo\react-native-windows\packages\E2ETest>yarn run bundle


Here is an example of error, and it doesn't provide useful information when this problem happens.
```
1>------ Build started: Project: ReactUWPTestApp, Configuration: Release x64 ------
1>  C:\repo\react-native-windows\packages\E2ETest
1>  yarn run v1.19.1
1>  $ just-scripts prepareBundle && react-native bundle --platform windows --entry-file dist/app/index.js --bundle-output windows/ReactUWPTestApp/Bundle/index.windows.bundle --assets-dest windows/ReactUWPTestApp/Bundle
1>  [6:06:23 PM]  started 'prepareBundle'
1>  [6:06:23 PM]  finished 'prepareBundle' in 0.01s
1>  Loading dependency graph, done.
1>  error Unable to resolve module `warnOnce` from `C:\repo\react-native-windows\node_modules\react-native\Libraries\react-native\react-native-implementation.js`: Module `warnOnce` does not exist in the Haste module map
1>  
1>  This might be related to https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/4968
1>  To resolve try the following:
1>    1. Clear watchman watches: `watchman watch-del-all`.
1>    2. Delete the `node_modules` folder: `rm -rf node_modules && npm install`.
1>    3. Reset Metro Bundler cache: `rm -rf /tmp/metro-bundler-cache-*` or `npm start -- --reset-cache`.
1>    4. Remove haste cache: `rm -rf /tmp/haste-map-react-native-packager-*`. Run CLI with --verbose flag for more details.
1>EXEC : error : Unable to resolve module `warnOnce` from `C:\repo\react-native-windows\node_modules\react-native\Libraries\react-native\react-native-implementation.js`: Module `warnOnce` does not exist in the Haste module map
1>  
1>  This might be related to https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/4968
1>  To resolve try the following:
1>    1. Clear watchman watches: `watchman watch-del-all`.
1>    2. Delete the `node_modules` folder: `rm -rf node_modules && npm install`.
1>    3. Reset Metro Bundler cache: `rm -rf /tmp/metro-bundler-cache-*` or `npm start -- --reset-cache`.
1>    4. Remove haste cache: `rm -rf /tmp/haste-map-react-native-packager-*`.
1>      at ModuleResolver.resolveDependency (C:\repo\react-native-windows\node_modules\metro\src\node-haste\DependencyGraph\ModuleResolution.js:183:15)
1>      at ResolutionRequest.resolveDependency (C:\repo\react-native-windows\node_modules\metro\src\node-haste\DependencyGraph\ResolutionRequest.js:52:18)
1>      at DependencyGraph.resolveDependency (C:\repo\react-native-windows\node_modules\metro\src\node-haste\DependencyGraph.js:283:16)
1>      at Object.resolve (C:\repo\react-native-windows\node_modules\metro\src\lib\transformHelpers.js:264:42)
1>      at dependencies.map.result (C:\repo\react-native-windows\node_modules\metro\src\DeltaBundler\traverseDependencies.js:399:31)

1>      at Generator.next (<anonymous>)
```

title: How to handle bundled assets

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
In the bundle command, there is bundle-output and also asserts-dest parameters. Even if I redirect asserts-dest to Asserts folder, it may still has problem to access the resource. Because the link is file://assets/abc in the bundled file, and the app expect it to be msappx://Assets/abc.

Andrew suggested It's possible to fork the logic in AssetSourceResolver to have it generate the right urls.

I also found an internal commit on this topic: 
https://github.com/Microsoft/react-native-windows/commit/2812a4506322917709fc6f27ac82f053c2414c4b

title: Discussion: React Native for Windows Roadmap and July updates
body:
# Updates
We announced the first public preview of React Native for Windows - vnext project at Microsoft BUILD 2019 conference earlier this year. You can watch the presentation - [React Native: Build rich Windows and mobile applications easily using JavaScript](https://mybuild.techcommunity.microsoft.com/sessions/77007) for more details.

We have since been making steady progress in the past several months, you can read about these in our [July updates blog](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/master/blog/July2019Updates.md). 

# Roadmap feedback
We recently published a high level [prospective roadmap](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/master/blog/Roadmap2019.md) on React Native for Windows for 2019 through early 2020. We would like to hear your feedback and have some questions below:

-	What do you think about the overall plan outlined in the roadmap? Would it enable you to use React Native for Windows vNext for your new and existing apps?

-	Are there major high level features (or) updates that you are looking for that our roadmap does not cover towards the first stable RC later this year? 
_For example_  we are working on adding __[Hermes engine support](https://github.com/facebook/hermes)__ to React Native Windows in the ongoing [Milestone 3](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/milestone/17) (see Issues [2799](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/2799) and [58](https://github.com/facebook/hermes/issues/58)). 

      Are there other major features or updates you would like to see us tackling right away? Are there any specific tooling related investments you are looking for?

-	__Version updates__: We currently support React Native version 0.59. Our current plans are to try and keep up with React Native versions as we accomplish more feature parity. This would mean, we will be updating from 0.59 to 0.60 and then 0.61(?) as we work towards the stable release candidate later this year. This means, there is likely to be feature gaps between React-Native and React-Native-Windows vNext while targeting the same version. 

       We debated locking to an important version (say 0.59) and completing all the features needed for full parity  but landed on this approach instead as that helps us (and by extension, you) keep up with React Native versioning better. We would be willing to consider back-porting/fixing select features or issues in a previous version if enough customers are blocked by it. Do you have any feedback on this approach?

-	__Extensions__: We are working on adding APIs for native extensions, modules and view managers story for React Native for Windows vNext. Our intention is to first closely match the APIs from the [current version](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/master/current/docs/NativeModulesWindows.md). We will be looking into [Turbo modules](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals/issues/40), [Expo unimodules](https://docs.expo.io/versions/v33.0.0/bare/hello-world/#using-unimodulescore) in parallel. We would love to hear your feedback on this topic  what would you like to see us invest in this space?

title: Support for react-native-navigation by Wix

labels.name: Extensions
labels.description: Tracks issues against community modules and extensions

labels.name: needs PM design
labels.description: New feature or request

milestone.title: MVP+ (vNext M5)
milestone.description:
After completing a MVP and moving vNext as the default template, this milestone covers work to fill out as much functionality as possible without requiring [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3). Thus it will not achieve 100% core parity, but will increase completion.

Items of note:
- Match lean core (moving components out to extensions)
- Turbo Module support

body:
The 2 most popular navigation libraries for react-native are [react-navigation](https://github.com/react-navigation/react-navigation) and [react-native-navigation.](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/) 
As react-navigation is done on JS side, I am assuming this will be working out of the box.
However [react-native-navigation](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/) is built natively, for obvious performance reasons. Please add support for this library so we can also use native navigation with UWP.
